decision.title: PM Spajić Meets AFET Delegation, Calls Closing All EU Chapters by December 2026 'Unprecedented' Goal
decision.summary: Prime Minister Milojko Spajić met with the European Parliament's Foreign Affairs Committee (AFET) delegation led by David McAllister during their February 16-18 visit to Podgorica. Spajić described closing all negotiating chapters by December 2026 as 'an exceptionally ambitious task, probably without precedent' and called for political backing from all 27 EU member states. McAllister confirmed Montenegro and Albania are the most advanced candidate countries. Reported by European Western Balkans, Adria TV, and aktuelno.me.
decision.title_mne: Premijer Spajić se sastao sa delegacijom AFET-a i nazvao zatvaranje svih poglavlja EU do decembra 2026. ciljem 'bez presedana'
decision.summary_mne: Predsjednik Vlade Milojko Spajić sastao se sa delegacijom Odbora za spoljne poslove Evropskog parlamenta (AFET) na čelu sa Davidom McAllisterom tokom njihove posjete Podgorici od 16. do 18. februara. Spajić je opisao zatvaranje svih pregovaračkih poglavlja do decembra 2026. kao 'izuzetno ambiciozan zadatak, vjerovatno bez presedana' i pozvao na političku podršku svih 27 država članica EU. McAllister je potvrdio da su Crna Gora i Albanija najnaprednije kandidatske zemlje. Prenijeli Evropski zapadni Balkan, Adria TV i aktuelno.me.

assessments.summary: The Prime Minister's engagement with the AFET delegation and the ambitious goal of closing all EU negotiating chapters by December 2026 is a positive signal for Montenegro's European integration. However, from the Ministry of Interior's perspective, this timeline places extraordinary pressure on Chapters 23 (Judiciary and Fundamental Rights) and 24 (Justice, Freedom and Security), which are traditionally the most demanding and where Montenegro still has significant benchmarks to meet in areas of organized crime, corruption, border management, and police reform.
assessments.executive_summary: The ambition to close all EU chapters by December 2026 is commendable and reinforces Montenegro's frontrunner status, but the Ministry of Interior warns that Chapters 23 and 24 remain the critical bottleneck. Without accelerated delivery on organized crime track records, border management upgrades, and police capacity building in the next 10 months, this goal risks becoming a political declaration rather than an operational reality.
assessments.reasoning:
The meeting with the AFET delegation is diplomatically significant and reinforces Montenegro's position as the most advanced EU candidate. David McAllister's confirmation of this status is valuable political capital. However, the Ministry of Interior must assess this through the lens of operational readiness rather than political messaging.

Chapters 23 and 24 are the cornerstone of EU accession and fall squarely within the Ministry of Interior's domain. These chapters are governed by the 'last opened, last closed' principle, meaning they will determine the entire accession timeline. As of early 2026, Montenegro still faces interim benchmarks in several critical areas: establishing a credible track record in prosecuting high-level organized crime and corruption cases, completing police reform including depoliticization and merit-based recruitment, achieving full operational capacity for border management in line with Schengen acquis, and strengthening the asylum and migration management framework.

The 10-month window until December 2026 is extremely compressed for the depth of institutional reform required. The European Commission's annual reports have consistently noted that while Montenegro has a solid legal framework, implementation and track records lag behind. The Uprava policije (Police Directorate) needs continued investment in specialized units — particularly the Special Police Unit (SJB), cybercrime units, and the anti-corruption apparatus. The Specialized State Prosecutor's Office (SDT) requires stronger cooperation with law enforcement for complex financial investigations.

On border management, Montenegro's preparation for eventual Schengen integration requires significant investment in border crossing point infrastructure, integrated border management (IBM) systems, and interoperability with EU databases (SIS II, VIS, Eurodac). While progress has been made through regional cooperation frameworks like SELEC and PCC-SEE, the operational benchmarks for Chapter 24 demand more than incremental improvements.

The political call for support from all 27 EU member states is strategically sound — several member states have historically been skeptical about Western Balkans enlargement, and unanimous political backing is indeed necessary. However, political backing does not substitute for meeting technical benchmarks. The risk is that an overemphasis on political diplomacy may create the impression that accession is a political negotiation rather than a standards-based process, which could backfire with the European Commission and skeptical member states like the Netherlands and France.

Positively, the high-level engagement creates momentum and can be leveraged to accelerate reforms. The AFET visit provides an opportunity for the Ministry of Interior to showcase concrete results and secure additional EU pre-accession support (IPA III funds) for police modernization and border management upgrades.
key_concerns: Chapter 24 interim benchmarks on organized crime track records remain partially unmet with only 10 months to the stated deadline
Police reform and depoliticization of the Uprava policije has not reached the level expected by the European Commission
Border management infrastructure and IT system interoperability with EU databases require significant investment that cannot be completed by December 2026
Risk of political over-promising that may undermine credibility with the European Commission if benchmarks are not objectively met
Migration and asylum management capacity remains underdeveloped relative to EU standards, particularly given shifting Balkan route dynamics
Cybersecurity institutional capacity, following the 2022 ransomware attack on government systems, still requires structural strengthening
recommendations: Develop and publish a detailed Chapter 24 implementation roadmap with monthly milestones for the remaining 10 months, with clear Ministry of Interior ownership of deliverables
Accelerate high-profile organized crime and corruption prosecutions to build a demonstrable track record before the European Commission's autumn 2026 assessment
Fast-track procurement and deployment of integrated border management technology, leveraging IPA III funds and bilateral EU member state assistance
Establish a dedicated inter-ministerial task force co-chaired by the Ministry of Interior and Ministry of Justice to coordinate Chapter 23/24 closure activities
Request targeted EU twinning projects and TAIEX missions focused on police capacity gaps identified in the latest Commission progress report
Strengthen cybersecurity governance by operationalizing the national CERT and aligning with the EU NIS2 Directive framework ahead of accession

counter_proposal.title: Operational Acceleration Plan for Chapter 24 Closure
counter_proposal.summary: Rather than relying primarily on high-level political engagement, the Ministry of Interior would propose a parallel operational acceleration track that prioritizes measurable deliverables in law enforcement, border management, and organized crime prosecution — ensuring that the political ambition is backed by concrete institutional readiness.
key_changes: Create a Chapter 24 'War Room' — a dedicated coordination unit within the Ministry of Interior with weekly reporting to the Chief Negotiator and the PM's office
Prioritize 5-7 high-impact organized crime cases for prosecution completion before October 2026 to demonstrate track record
Launch emergency procurement for border management IT systems (biometric readers, AFIS upgrades, connection protocols for future SIS II access)
Deploy EU member state police liaison officers within Montenegrin law enforcement to provide real-time capacity building
Commission an independent operational readiness audit by Q2 2026 to identify and address remaining gaps before the Commission's assessment
expected_benefits: Converts political ambition into verifiable operational benchmarks that satisfy European Commission methodology
Reduces the risk of accession timeline slipping due to unmet Chapter 24 requirements
Demonstrates to skeptical EU member states that Montenegro's progress is standards-based, not politically negotiated
Strengthens institutional capacity that will endure beyond the accession process
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: Moderately feasible within the 10-month timeframe if political will is matched with adequate budget allocation and EU technical assistance is mobilized immediately. The main constraint is procurement timelines for border management technology, which may require emergency procedures under Montenegrin public procurement law.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Plan operativnog ubrzanja za zatvaranje Poglavlja 24
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Umjesto da se primarno oslanja na visokopolitičko angažovanje, Ministarstvo unutrašnjih poslova predlaže paralelni operativni ubrzani pravac koji daje prioritet mjerljivim rezultatima u oblasti policijskog rada, upravljanja granicama i gonjenja organizovanog kriminala — osiguravajući da političke ambicije budu potkrijepljene konkretnom institucionalnom spremnošću.
key_changes_mne: Uspostavljanje 'Ratne sobe' za Poglavlje 24 — posebne koordinacione jedinice unutar Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova s nedjeljnim izvještavanjem Glavnom pregovaraču i kabinetu predsjednika Vlade
Davanje prioriteta 5–7 visokouticajnih predmeta organizovanog kriminala radi okončanja krivičnog gonjenja prije oktobra 2026. godine, s ciljem dokazivanja konkretnih rezultata
Pokretanje hitne nabavke IT sistema za upravljanje granicama (biometrijski čitači, nadogradnja AFIS-a, komunikacijski protokoli za budući pristup SIS II)
Raspoređivanje policijskih oficira za vezu iz država članica EU unutar crnogorskih organa za sprovođenje zakona radi pružanja podrške izgradnji kapaciteta u realnom vremenu
Naručivanje nezavisne revizije operativne spremnosti do drugog kvartala 2026. godine, s ciljem identifikovanja i otklanjanja preostalih nedostataka prije ocjene Evropske komisije
expected_benefits_mne: Pretvara političke ambicije u provjerljive operativne referentne vrijednosti koje zadovoljavaju metodologiju Evropske komisije
Smanjuje rizik od kašnjenja u ostvarivanju pristupnih rokova zbog neispunjenih zahtjeva iz Poglavlja 24
Dokazuje skeptičnim državama članicama EU da napredak Crne Gore počiva na standardima, a ne na političkim pregovorima
Jača institucionalne kapacitete koji će biti održivi i nakon završetka pristupnog procesa
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Umjereno ostvarivo u okviru vremenskog perioda od 10 mjeseci, pod uslovom da politička volja bude praćena odgovarajućim budžetskim izdvajanjima i da se tehnička pomoć EU odmah mobilizuje. Glavni ograničavajući faktor su rokovi nabavke tehnologije za upravljanje granicama, za šta mogu biti potrebne hitne procedure u skladu sa crnogorskim zakonom o javnim nabavkama.

assessments.summary_mne: Angažovanje premijera s delegacijom AFET-a i ambiciozni cilj zatvaranja svih pregovaračkih poglavlja EU do decembra 2026. godine predstavljaju pozitivan signal za evropsku integraciju Crne Gore. Međutim, iz perspektive Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova, ovaj vremenski okvir stavlja izuzetan pritisak na Poglavlja 23 (Pravosuđe i osnovna prava) i 24 (Pravda, sloboda i bezbjednost), koja su tradicionalno najzahtjevnija i u kojima Crna Gora još uvijek ima značajne referentne vrijednosti koje treba ispuniti u oblastima organizovanog kriminala, korupcije, upravljanja granicama i reforme policije.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ambicija zatvaranja svih poglavlja EU do decembra 2026. godine pohvalna je i učvršćuje status Crne Gore kao predvodnika, ali Ministarstvo unutrašnjih poslova upozorava da Poglavlja 23 i 24 ostaju ključno usko grlo. Bez ubrzane isporuke rezultata u oblasti organizovanog kriminala, unapređenja upravljanja granicama i izgradnje policijskih kapaciteta u narednih 10 mjeseci, ovaj cilj riskiruje da ostane politička deklaracija, a ne operativna stvarnost.
key_concerns_mne: Privremeni referentni ciljevi iz Poglavlja 24 o evidenciji rezultata u borbi protiv organizovanog kriminala djelimično su neispunjeni, a do navedenog roka ostalo je svega 10 mjeseci

Rizik od političkog preobećavanja koje može narušiti kredibilitet pred Evropskom komisijom ukoliko referentni ciljevi objektivno ne budu ispunjeni
Kapaciteti za upravljanje migracijama i azilom i dalje su nedovoljno razvijeni u odnosu na standarde EU, posebno s obzirom na promjenljivu dinamiku balkanske rute
Institucionalni kapaciteti u oblasti kibernetičke bezbjednosti, nakon ransomware napada na državne sisteme iz 2022. godine, još uvijek zahtijevaju strukturalno jačanje
recommendations_mne: Izraditi i objaviti detaljan plan implementacije Poglavlja 24 s mjesečnim prekretnicama za preostalih 10 mjeseci, uz jasno vlasništvo Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova nad isporukama
Ubrzati krivična gonjenja u visokoprofilnim predmetima organizovanog kriminala i korupcije kako bi se izgradila dokaziva evidencija rezultata prije jesenje procjene Evropske komisije 2026. godine
Ubrzati nabavku i uvođenje integrisane tehnologije za upravljanje granicama, koristeći fondove IPA III i bilateralnu pomoć država članica EU
Uspostaviti namjensku međuresornu radnu grupu u supredsjedavanju Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova i Ministarstva pravde radi koordinacije aktivnosti na zatvaranju Poglavlja 23 i 24
Zatražiti ciljane projekte EU twinning-a i TAIEX misije usmjerene na nedostatke u policijskim kapacitetima identifikovane u posljednjem izvještaju Komisije o napretku
Ojačati upravljanje kibernetičkom bezbjednošću operacionalizacijom nacionalnog CERT-a i usklađivanjem s okvirom Direktive EU NIS2 prije pristupanja

assessments.summary: The Prime Minister's ambition to close all EU negotiating chapters by December 2026 is a broadly positive signal for the health sector, as it implies accelerated alignment with the EU health acquis under Chapter 28 (Consumer and Health Protection) and related chapters. However, the compressed timeline raises serious concerns about whether Montenegro's healthcare system can achieve genuine reform — not just legislative transposition — within 10 months, particularly given chronic underfunding, workforce emigration, and institutional capacity gaps.
assessments.executive_summary: The EU accession push is welcome for health sector modernization, but the 10-month timeline risks superficial legislative alignment without real improvements in patient safety, health workforce retention, or pharmaceutical regulation. The Ministry of Health urges that Chapter 28 benchmarks be met through substantive reform, not paper compliance, and that health sector investment be treated as a precondition for credible closure.
assessments.reasoning:
Chapter 28 — Consumer and Health Protection — is one of the chapters that Montenegro must close, and it encompasses critical areas: cross-border healthcare, communicable disease surveillance, tobacco control, blood and tissue safety, pharmaceutical regulation, and patient rights. While Montenegro has made progress in transposing EU directives in these areas, the gap between legislative adoption and effective implementation remains wide.

The PM's meeting with the AFET delegation and the declaration of an 'unprecedented' goal to close all chapters by December 2026 creates political momentum that can benefit health reform. EU pressure and benchmarking have historically been the most effective drivers of institutional change in Montenegro's health sector — from upgrading the Clinical Center of Montenegro to reforming the RFZO (Health Insurance Fund) reimbursement lists.

However, several structural realities temper optimism. First, Montenegro's health workforce crisis is acute. An estimated 300-500 doctors have left for EU countries (Germany, Slovenia, Croatia) in recent years, and the country produces only ~150 medical graduates per year. Accelerated EU alignment without a workforce retention strategy could paradoxically worsen brain drain, as mutual recognition of qualifications (a Chapter 28/acquis requirement) makes emigration even easier. Second, pharmaceutical policy alignment — particularly with EU pricing and reimbursement transparency directives — requires not just legal changes but administrative capacity that the Agency for Medicines and Medical Devices (CInMED) currently struggles to maintain with limited staff. Third, patient safety and quality standards in hospitals outside Podgorica remain far below EU norms, and genuine compliance would require capital investment that is not reflected in current budget projections.

The political framing of this goal as 'unprecedented' is accurate but also concerning. It signals awareness that the timeline is extremely tight, which in health policy typically leads to prioritizing legislative box-ticking over genuine system strengthening. The Ministry of Health must insist that closing Chapter 28 is not reduced to a checklist exercise but is accompanied by measurable outcomes — hospital accreditation, reduced avoidable mortality, functional e-health systems, and a credible health workforce strategy.

On the positive side, AFET confirmation that Montenegro is the most advanced candidate country gives political leverage to demand increased EU pre-accession health funding (IPA III) and technical assistance, which could be transformative if channeled effectively.
key_concerns: 10-month timeline risks superficial transposition of EU health directives without genuine implementation or enforcement capacity
Accelerated mutual recognition of medical qualifications may worsen health workforce brain drain to EU member states
CInMED and RFZO lack administrative capacity to fully implement EU pharmaceutical pricing, pharmacovigilance, and reimbursement transparency requirements by year-end
Hospital infrastructure outside Podgorica (Nikšić, Bijelo Polje, Bar) is far from EU patient safety and quality standards
No visible health sector investment plan accompanying the political ambition — risk of unfunded mandates
Mental health and primary care reform, critical for EU alignment, remain significantly underdeveloped
recommendations: Develop a Chapter 28 health implementation roadmap with specific milestones, responsible institutions, and budget lines — not just legislative targets
Negotiate with the European Commission for enhanced IPA III health sector funding and twinning projects specifically tied to chapter closure benchmarks
Immediately launch a health workforce retention package (salary supplements, specialization funding, housing incentives) to counterbalance emigration pressure from enhanced qualification recognition
Strengthen CInMED staffing and IT systems to handle EU pharmacovigilance, clinical trial regulation (EU CTR alignment), and medical device regulation (MDR) requirements

Establish a joint Health-EU Integration task force to ensure the Ministry of Health has a seat at the negotiating table and that health benchmarks reflect substantive outcomes, not just transposition counts
Prioritize e-health infrastructure (electronic health records, cross-border prescription systems) as both a Chapter 28 requirement and a practical system improvement

counter_proposal.title: Substantive Health Acquis Alignment with Workforce Safeguards
counter_proposal.summary: Rather than pursuing pure legislative transposition speed, the Ministry of Health would propose a dual-track approach: fast-track alignment on areas where Montenegro is already close to compliance (tobacco control, communicable disease surveillance, blood safety) while requesting transitional periods or implementation milestones for complex areas (pharmaceutical regulation, hospital quality standards, cross-border healthcare). Simultaneously, a binding health workforce retention strategy would be adopted as a precondition for closing Chapter 28, ensuring that EU accession strengthens rather than hollows out the domestic health system.
key_changes: Classify Chapter 28 sub-areas into 'ready for closure' and 'needs transitional arrangements' categories with honest assessment

Adopt a Health Workforce Retention Act before chapter closure, including competitive salary benchmarks, mandatory return-of-service agreements for state-funded specializations, and diaspora engagement programs
Request EU technical assistance missions specifically for CInMED capacity building and RFZO reform
Link chapter closure to measurable health outcomes (e.g., avoidable mortality rate targets, hospital accreditation percentages) rather than purely legislative metrics
expected_benefits: Credible and sustainable EU alignment that survives post-accession scrutiny
Reduced risk of health system collapse from accelerated brain drain
Stronger negotiating position with the Commission by demonstrating genuine reform commitment
Improved public trust in EU accession process through visible health system improvements
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: Moderately feasible. The dual-track approach is consistent with how other candidate countries (Croatia, Romania) handled Chapter 28, and transitional arrangements are standard EU practice. The workforce retention measures require political will and modest budget reallocation (~€5-10M annually) but are achievable. The main risk is political resistance to admitting that not all sub-areas are ready for immediate closure.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Suštinsko usklađivanje zdravstvenog acquisa sa zaštitom radne snage
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Umjesto čistog ubrzavanja zakonodavne transpozicije, Ministarstvo zdravlja predložilo bi pristup s dvije linije djelovanja: ubrzano usklađivanje u oblastima u kojima je Crna Gora već blizu ispunjavanja uslova (kontrola duhana, nadzor zaraznih bolesti, bezbjednost krvi), uz istovremeno traženje prelaznih perioda ili razvojnih prekretnica za složene oblasti (regulacija lijekova, standardi kvaliteta bolnica, prekogranična zdravstvena zaštita). Istovremeno, obavezujuća strategija zadržavanja zdravstvene radne snage usvojila bi se kao preduslov za zatvaranje Poglavlja 28, čime bi se osiguralo da pristupanje EU ojača, a ne oslabi domaći zdravstveni sistem.
key_changes_mne: Klasifikovati podoblasti Poglavlja 28 u kategorije 'spremno za zatvaranje' i 'zahtijeva prelazne aranžmane' uz iskrenu procjenu stanja

Usvojiti Zakon o zadržavanju zdravstvene radne snage prije zatvaranja poglavlja, uključujući konkurentne referentne vrijednosti zarada, obavezne ugovore o povratku službe za specijalizacije finansirane od strane države i programe angažovanja dijaspore
Zatražiti misije tehničke pomoći EU posebno namijenjene jačanju kapaciteta CInMED-a i reformi RFZO-a
Usloviti zatvaranje poglavlja mjerljivim zdravstvenim ishodima (npr. ciljnim stopama izbjegive smrtnosti, procentima akreditacije bolnica), a ne isključivo zakonodavnim pokazateljima
expected_benefits_mne: Vjerodostojno i održivo usklađivanje s EU koje izdržava provjeru nakon pristupanja
Smanjen rizik od urušavanja zdravstvenog sistema usljed ubrzanog odliva mozgova
Jača pregovaračka pozicija s Komisijom kroz dokazivanje istinske posvećenosti reformama
Povećano povjerenje javnosti u proces pristupanja EU kroz vidljiva poboljšanja zdravstvenog sistema
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Umjereno ostvarivo. Pristup s dvije linije djelovanja u skladu je s načinom na koji su druge kandidatske zemlje (Hrvatska, Rumunija) postupale s Poglavljem 28, a prelazni aranžmani predstavljaju standardnu praksu EU. Mjere zadržavanja radne snage zahtijevaju političku volju i skromnu preraspodjelu budžeta (oko 5–10 miliona eura godišnje), ali su dostižne. Glavni rizik leži u političkom otporu prema priznavanju da nisu sve podoblasti spremne za trenutno zatvaranje.

assessments.summary_mne: Ambicija premijera da zatvori sva pregovaračka poglavlja s EU do decembra 2026. predstavlja uglavnom pozitivan signal za zdravstveni sektor, jer podrazumijeva ubrzano usklađivanje s EU zdravstvenom pravnom tekovinom u okviru Poglavlja 28 (Zaštita potrošača i zdravlja) i srodnih poglavlja. Međutim, stisnuti vremenski okvir izaziva ozbiljnu zabrinutost u pogledu toga da li crnogorski zdravstveni sistem može postići stvarnu reformu — a ne samo zakonodavno preuzimanje propisa — u roku od 10 mjeseci, posebno uzimajući u obzir hronično nedovoljno finansiranje, iseljavanje zdravstvenih radnika i nedostatke u institucionalnim kapacitetima.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Pritisak za pristupanje EU pozdravlja se kao podsticaj za modernizaciju zdravstvenog sektora, ali desetomjesečni vremenski okvir prijeti površnim zakonodavnim usklađivanjem bez stvarnih poboljšanja u oblasti bezbjednosti pacijenata, zadržavanja zdravstvenih radnika ili farmaceutske regulacije. Ministarstvo zdravlja insistira na tome da referentna mjerila iz Poglavlja 28 budu ispunjena kroz suštinsku reformu, a ne formalnu usklađenost na papiru, te da se ulaganje u zdravstveni sektor tretira kao preduslov za vjerodostojno zatvaranje poglavlja.
key_concerns_mne: Desetomjesečni vremenski rok prijeti površnim preuzimanjem EU zdravstvenih direktiva bez stvarnih kapaciteta za implementaciju ili sprovođenje
Ubrzano međusobno priznavanje medicinskih kvalifikacija može pogoršati odliv zdravstvenih kadrova u države članice EU
CInMED i RFZO nemaju dovoljne administrativne kapacitete da do kraja godine u potpunosti sprovedu EU zahtjeve u oblasti farmaceutskih cijena, farmakovigilance i transparentnosti refundacije
Bolnička infrastruktura van Podgorice (Nikšić, Bijelo Polje, Bar) daleko je ispod EU standarda bezbjednosti pacijenata i kvaliteta usluga
Ne postoji vidljiv investicioni plan za zdravstveni sektor koji prati političke ambicije — postoji rizik od nefinansiranih obaveza
Reforma mentalnog zdravlja i primarne zdravstvene zaštite, ključna za usklađivanje s EU, i dalje je značajno nerazvijena
recommendations_mne: Izraditi plan implementacije zdravstvenih mjera u okviru Poglavlja 28 s konkretnim prekretnicama, odgovornim institucijama i budžetskim stavkama — a ne samo zakonodavnim ciljevima
Pregovarati s Evropskom komisijom o povećanom finansiranju zdravstvenog sektora kroz IPA III i tvining projektima koji su konkretno vezani za referentna mjerila za zatvaranje poglavlja

Odmah pokrenuti paket mjera za zadržavanje zdravstvenih radnika (dodaci na plate, finansiranje specijalizacija, stambene podsticaje) kako bi se neutralisao pritisak iseljavanja usljed poboljšanog priznavanja kvalifikacija
Ojačati kadrove i IT sisteme CInMED-a kako bi se ispunili EU zahtjevi u oblasti farmakovigilance, regulacije kliničkih ispitivanja (usklađivanje s EU CTR) i regulacije medicinskih uređaja (MDR)

Uspostaviti zajednički Radni tim za zdravlje i EU integracije kako bi se osiguralo da Ministarstvo zdravlja ima svoje mjesto za pregovaračkim stolom i da zdravstvena referentna mjerila odražavaju suštinske ishode, a ne samo broj prenesenih propisa
Dati prioritet e-zdravstvenoj infrastrukturi (elektronski zdravstveni kartoni, sistemi prekograničnih recepata) kao zahtjevu Poglavlja 28 i praktičnom unapređenju sistema

assessments.summary: The Prime Minister's meeting with the AFET delegation and the ambitious target of closing all EU negotiating chapters by December 2026 sends a strong signal to investors and economic actors about Montenegro's European trajectory. While the goal is economically beneficial as a credibility anchor, the Ministry of Economy notes that the timeline is extremely compressed, and the real economic value depends entirely on whether substantive regulatory alignment — particularly in chapters directly affecting the economy (Competition, Company Law, Free Movement of Capital, Energy, Industrial Policy) — is genuinely achieved rather than merely formally closed.
assessments.executive_summary: The ambitious December 2026 target for closing all EU chapters is a net positive for economic confidence and FDI signaling, but risks becoming counterproductive if formal chapter closure outpaces genuine regulatory and institutional alignment. The Ministry of Economy recommends anchoring this political goal in a concrete economic reform delivery plan, particularly for competition policy, energy transition, and industrial competitiveness.
assessments.reasoning:
From an economic development perspective, a credible EU accession timeline is one of the most powerful instruments Montenegro has for attracting foreign direct investment, reducing country risk premiums, and anchoring macroeconomic stability. Montenegro's small, open economy (~6B EUR GDP) is disproportionately sensitive to external confidence signals, and confirmed frontrunner status from David McAllister reinforces Montenegro's positioning vis-à-vis regional competitors for investment flows.

However, the Ministry of Economy must flag several substantive concerns. First, several negotiating chapters are directly within our domain — Chapter 6 (Company Law), Chapter 8 (Competition Policy), Chapter 15 (Energy), Chapter 20 (Enterprise and Industrial Policy), and Chapter 4 (Free Movement of Capital). These chapters require not just legislative transposition but functioning institutional capacity: an independent competition authority, a functional energy regulator, effective state aid control, and a business environment genuinely aligned with the Single Market acquis. Rushing formal closure without real institutional depth could create a 'Potemkin alignment' that collapses upon accession scrutiny or, worse, leaves Montenegrin firms unprepared for full Single Market competition.

Second, on FDI, while the announcement is positive for investor sentiment in the short term, sophisticated investors — particularly in manufacturing, energy, and technology — look beyond political declarations to actual regulatory predictability, rule of law, and enforcement capacity. Montenegro's FDI remains heavily concentrated in real estate and tourism, and diversification toward higher-value sectors requires demonstrable improvements in competition enforcement, intellectual property protection, and energy supply reliability, not merely chapter closure.

Third, the energy chapter (Chapter 15) is particularly critical. Montenegro faces binding obligations under the Energy Community Treaty, including coal phase-out planning for Pljevlja TPP, renewable energy deployment, and electricity market liberalization. Closing this chapter formally without resolving the Pljevlja decarbonization pathway and ensuring affordable, reliable industrial energy supply could create acute problems for the northern region's economy and for energy-intensive SMEs.

Fourth, the labor market dimension is underexplored in this announcement. EU accession preparation should include concrete measures to address skills gaps, reduce informal employment (estimated at 20-30% of the economy), and prepare Montenegrin workers and firms for labor mobility within the Single Market. Without such preparation, accession could trigger brain drain acceleration rather than economic convergence.

The political backing request to all 27 member states is pragmatic — Montenegro's progress can be blocked by bilateral issues with individual members — but the Ministry of Economy would emphasize that the strongest argument for member state support is demonstrated economic reform delivery, not diplomatic lobbying alone.

FDI signaling benefit may be short-lived if substantive reforms in business environment, rule of law, and regulatory predictability do not follow
Energy chapter closure without a credible Pljevlja TPP decarbonization plan and renewable energy investment pipeline could create energy security and affordability risks for industry
No accompanying labor market preparation strategy to mitigate brain drain risk and informal economy challenges upon accession
SMEs and domestic firms may be unprepared for full Single Market competition if alignment is rushed without transition support programs
Concentration of FDI in real estate and tourism remains unaddressed — chapter closure alone will not diversify the investment base
recommendations: Develop and publish a detailed Economic Reform Delivery Plan mapping each economy-related chapter to specific institutional milestones, not just legislative transposition
Prioritize functional independence and capacity of the Agency for Protection of Competition and the Energy Regulatory Agency as preconditions for credible chapter closure
Adopt a Pljevlja TPP decarbonization roadmap with clear timelines and just transition measures for the northern region before formal closure of the energy chapter

Launch an SME Single Market Readiness Program to prepare Montenegrin small businesses for competitive pressures post-accession, including standards compliance, digital transformation, and export capacity building
Integrate labor market reforms — skills development, formalization incentives, and active labor market policies — into the accession timeline as economic chapter benchmarks
Use the AFET engagement to advocate for pre-accession access to EU structural and cohesion funds to support economic convergence and reduce regional disparities

counter_proposal.title: Economic Substance-First Accession Strategy
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Economy would complement the ambitious political timeline with a parallel 'Economic Readiness Scorecard' that tracks not chapter closure but actual economic alignment outcomes — competition enforcement cases, energy market liberalization metrics, FDI diversification indicators, SME competitiveness benchmarks, and labor formalization rates. This ensures that the December 2026 target drives real economic reform rather than cosmetic compliance, and provides the EU with evidence-based confidence in Montenegro's readiness.
key_changes: Introduce a quarterly Economic Readiness Scorecard with measurable indicators for each economy-related chapter, published transparently
Condition chapter closure requests on demonstrated institutional capacity (e.g., competition authority case throughput, energy regulator independence assessment)
Establish a €20M SME Competitiveness Fund financed through IPA III to support firms in meeting EU standards and accessing Single Market opportunities
Create a Joint Commission on Just Transition for Northern Montenegro to manage the socioeconomic impact of coal phase-out alongside chapter closure
Negotiate early access to select EU programs (InvestEU, COSME successor) as a demonstration of mutual commitment
expected_benefits: Higher quality accession that protects Montenegrin firms from competitive shock upon EU entry
Diversified FDI attracted by genuine regulatory credibility rather than political declarations alone
Reduced brain drain risk through visible domestic economic opportunity creation
Stronger negotiating position with EU member states based on demonstrable reform delivery
Sustainable energy transition pathway that supports rather than undermines industrial competitiveness
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High feasibility. The scorecard approach requires no additional legislation, only political will and coordination. The SME fund can be structured under existing IPA III allocations. The just transition commission builds on existing government structures. The main constraint is institutional coordination capacity across ministries, which itself is a useful stress test of accession readiness.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Strategija pristupanja s primarnim fokusom na ekonomsku suštinu
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo ekonomije bi dopunilo ambiciozni politički vremenski okvir paralelnom 'Kartom ekonomske spremnosti' koja prati ne zatvaranje poglavlja, već stvarne ishode ekonomskog usklađivanja — slučajeve primjene propisa o zaštiti tržišnog natjecanja, pokazatelje liberalizacije tržišta energije, indikatore diversifikacije stranih direktnih investicija, mjerila konkurentnosti malih i srednjih preduzeća te stope formalizacije rada. Time se osigurava da cilj iz decembra 2026. pokreće stvarne ekonomske reforme, a ne kozmetičku usklađenost, te da EU-u pruža utemeljeno povjerenje u spremnost Crne Gore.
key_changes_mne: Uvesti tromjesečnu Kartu ekonomske spremnosti s mjerljivim pokazateljima za svako poglavlje vezano za ekonomiju, koja se objavljuje transparentno
Uvjetovati zahtjeve za zatvaranje poglavlja dokazanim institucionalnim kapacitetima (npr. broj predmeta tijela za zaštitu tržišnog natjecanja, procjena nezavisnosti regulatora energetike)

Uspostaviti Fond za konkurentnost malih i srednjih preduzeća u iznosu od 20 miliona eura, finansiran kroz IPA III, radi podrške preduzećima u ispunjavanju EU standarda i pristupu prilikama na Jedinstvenom tržištu
Osnovati Zajedničku komisiju za pravednu tranziciju Sjeverne Crne Gore radi upravljanja socioekonomskim posljedicama postupnog ukidanja uglja, usporedno sa zatvaranjem poglavlja
Pregovarati o ranom pristupu pojedinim EU programima (InvestEU, nasljednik COSME-a) kao dokaz obostrane posvećenosti

Diversifikovane strane direktne investicije privučene stvarnim regulatornim kredibilitetom, a ne samo političkim izjavama
Smanjen rizik od odliva mozgova kroz vidljivo stvaranje domaćih ekonomskih prilika

Održivi put energetske tranzicije koji podupire, a ne podriva industrijsku konkurentnost
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka izvodljivost. Pristup zasnovan na karti bodova ne zahtijeva dodatno zakonodavstvo, već samo političku volju i koordinaciju. Fond za mala i srednja preduzeća može se strukturirati u okviru postojećih alokacija IPA III. Komisija za pravednu tranziciju nadograđuje postojeće vladine strukture. Glavni ograničavajući faktor je kapacitet institucijske koordinacije između ministarstava, što je samo po sebi koristan test pritiska na spremnost za pristupanje.

assessments.summary_mne: Sastanak predsjednika Vlade sa delegacijom AFET-a i ambiciozni cilj zatvaranja svih pregovaračkih poglavlja EU do decembra 2026. šalje snažan signal investitorima i ekonomskim akterima o evropskom putu Crne Gore. Iako je ovaj cilj ekonomski koristan kao sidro kredibiliteta, Ministarstvo ekonomije napominje da je vremenski okvir izuzetno sažet, te da stvarna ekonomska vrijednost u potpunosti zavisi od toga da li će suštinsko usklađivanje propisa — posebno u poglavljima koja neposredno utiču na privredu (Konkurencija, Pravo privrednih društava, Slobodno kretanje kapitala, Energetika, Industrijska politika) — biti istinski postignuto, a ne samo formalno zatvoreno.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ambiciozni cilj zatvaranja svih poglavlja EU do decembra 2026. neto je pozitivan za ekonomsko povjerenje i privlačenje stranih direktnih investicija, ali nosi rizik od kontraproduktivnosti ukoliko formalno zatvaranje poglavlja pretekne stvarno regulatorno i institucionalno usklađivanje. Ministarstvo ekonomije preporučuje da se ovaj politički cilj utemelji u konkretnom planu realizacije ekonomskih reformi, posebno u oblastima politike konkurencije, energetske tranzicije i industrijske konkurentnosti.
key_concerns_mne: Rizik od formalnog zatvaranja poglavlja bez stvarnih institucionalnih kapaciteta u oblasti konkurencije, energetike i industrijske politike — čime se stvaraju regulatorne praznine koje štete crnogorskim preduzećima po pristupanju
Korist po privlačenje stranih direktnih investicija može biti kratkotrajna ukoliko suštinske reforme poslovnog ambijenta, vladavine prava i regulatorne predvidivosti izostanu

Zatvaranje energetskog poglavlja bez vjerodostojnog plana dekarbonizacije TE Pljevlja i razvojnog plana ulaganja u obnovljive izvore energije moglo bi stvoriti rizike po energetsku bezbjednost i pristupačnost energije za industriju
Izostanak prateće strategije pripreme tržišta rada za ublažavanje rizika od odliva mozgova i izazova sive ekonomije po pristupanju
Mala i srednja preduzeća i domaće kompanije mogu biti nepripremljene za punu konkurenciju na Jedinstvenom tržištu ukoliko se usklađivanje sprovede ubrzano bez programa podrške u prelaznom periodu
Koncentracija stranih direktnih investicija u nekretninama i turizmu ostaje neriješena — samo zatvaranje poglavlja neće diversifikovati investicionu osnovu
recommendations_mne: Izraditi i objaviti detaljan Plan realizacije ekonomskih reformi koji svako poglavlje vezano za privredu mapira na konkretne institucionalne prekretnice, a ne samo na zakonodavno prenošenje propisa
Prioritetno obezbijediti funkcionalnu nezavisnost i kapacitete Agencije za zaštitu konkurencije i Regulatorne agencije za energetiku kao preduslove za vjerodostojno zatvaranje poglavlja
Usvojiti plan dekarbonizacije TE Pljevlja sa jasnim rokovima i mjerama pravedne tranzicije za sjeverni region prije formalnog zatvaranja energetskog poglavlja

Integrisati reforme tržišta rada — razvoj vještina, podsticaje za formalizaciju i aktivne politike tržišta rada — u vremenski okvir pristupanja kao mjerila u ekonomskim poglavljima

Iskoristiti saradnju s AFET-om zaради zalaganja za pristup strukturnim fondovima i fondovima kohezije EU u pretpristupnom periodu, u cilju podrške ekonomskoj konvergenciji i smanjenja regionalnih neravnomjernosti

assessments.summary: The Prime Minister's commitment to closing all EU negotiating chapters by December 2026 is broadly positive for the education sector, as it creates strong political momentum for aligning Montenegro's education system with EU standards. However, the 'unprecedented' ambition of this timeline raises serious concerns about whether education-related benchmarks—particularly in Chapter 26 (Education and Culture) and Chapter 25 (Science and Research)—can be substantively met rather than merely formally closed, risking superficial compliance over genuine reform.
assessments.executive_summary: This ambitious EU accession push is positive for education as it accelerates alignment with European standards, but the compressed December 2026 deadline risks producing paper compliance rather than real improvements in teaching quality, VET reform, and research capacity. The Ministry's top concern is that education chapters may be rushed to closure without addressing structural weaknesses like brain drain, underfunded universities, and poor PISA performance.
assessments.reasoning:
Montenegro's EU accession process directly implicates the education sector through several negotiating chapters, most notably Chapter 26 (Education and Culture), Chapter 25 (Science and Research), and indirectly Chapter 19 (Social Policy and Employment, covering VET and lifelong learning). The PM's meeting with the AFET delegation and his framing of closing all chapters by December 2026 as 'unprecedented' signals both ambition and implicit acknowledgment of the difficulty ahead.

From an education perspective, Montenegro has made progress on formal alignment: the Bologna Process has been adopted, the Montenegrin Qualifications Framework (MQF) has been developed to align with the European Qualifications Framework (EQF), and participation in Erasmus+ has expanded. However, substantive gaps remain significant. Montenegro's PISA scores consistently rank well below the EU average, indicating systemic weaknesses in basic and secondary education quality. The University of Montenegro, the country's primary public university, faces chronic underfunding, aging infrastructure, and limited research output. Teacher salaries remain among the lowest in the region, contributing to low motivation and difficulty attracting talent into the profession.

The accelerated timeline creates a double-edged dynamic. On one hand, political pressure from the top—backed by engagement with figures like David McAllister—can unblock stalled reforms, release EU pre-accession funding (IPA III) more efficiently, and create accountability mechanisms for the education ministry. On the other hand, there is a well-documented risk in Western Balkan accession processes of 'box-ticking'—formally adopting EU-aligned legislation and frameworks without building the institutional capacity to implement them. This is particularly dangerous in education, where outcomes depend on years of sustained investment in teacher training, curriculum reform, and infrastructure.

Brain drain is perhaps the most acute concern. Montenegro loses a disproportionate share of its educated youth to EU countries, and paradoxically, deeper EU integration and the prospect of accession may accelerate this outflow if domestic education and employment conditions do not improve in tandem. If chapters are closed without addressing the root causes of youth emigration—poor labor market prospects for graduates, low research funding, limited VET pathways linked to real employer demand—the accession process could hollow out the very human capital needed to sustain EU membership obligations.

The confirmation by McAllister that Montenegro is among the most advanced candidates is encouraging and provides leverage. But the Ministry of Education must ensure this political capital translates into concrete resource allocation, not just diplomatic statements. The VET system in particular needs urgent modernization to meet EU standards on work-based learning, employer engagement, and quality assurance—areas where Montenegro remains behind countries like Serbia and North Macedonia in certain metrics.

Ultimately, this decision is positive because it sustains accession momentum, which is the single strongest external driver of education reform in Montenegro. But the Ministry must be vigilant that speed does not come at the expense of depth.
key_concerns: Compressed timeline risks formal/paper compliance in Chapter 26 (Education and Culture) without substantive improvements in teaching quality or student outcomes
Brain drain may accelerate as EU accession becomes more tangible, without parallel investments in domestic education quality and graduate employment
PISA performance gaps remain unaddressed and cannot be resolved by chapter closure alone—Montenegro's scores lag significantly behind EU averages
VET reform—including work-based learning, employer partnerships, and quality assurance—requires multi-year institutional development that cannot be rushed to meet a December 2026 deadline
The University of Montenegro and research institutions lack the funding and capacity to meet Chapter 25 (Science and Research) benchmarks in a meaningful way
Teacher workforce challenges (low salaries, insufficient professional development, aging workforce) are structural and risk being deprioritized in favor of legislatively easier benchmarks
recommendations: Ensure the education sector receives a dedicated action plan under the accelerated accession framework, with specific milestones for Chapter 26 and Chapter 25 that go beyond legislative alignment
Negotiate with the European Commission for transitional implementation periods on education benchmarks that require multi-year capacity building, even if chapters are formally closed
Maximize IPA III and Erasmus+ funding absorption specifically for teacher training, VET modernization, and university research capacity
Establish a brain drain monitoring and mitigation unit linked to the accession process, tracking youth emigration data and linking retention incentives to EU-funded scholarship programs
Fast-track alignment of the Montenegrin Qualifications Framework (MQF) with EQF Level 5-8 standards, particularly for VET and higher education micro-credentials

Use AFET engagement to advocate for Montenegro's inclusion in EU research framework programs (Horizon Europe associated country status) as a concrete accession benefit for the education and research sector

counter_proposal.title: Education Substance-First Accession Strategy
counter_proposal.summary: Rather than treating education chapters as items to be formally closed by December 2026, the Ministry would propose a parallel track: formal chapter closure accompanied by a binding 5-year Education Accession Implementation Roadmap (2026-2031) with measurable outcome targets (e.g., PISA score improvement, VET completion rates, research output metrics, brain drain reduction targets). This would allow Montenegro to maintain accession momentum while ensuring EU membership is underpinned by genuine education system capacity.
key_changes: Adopt a binding Education Accession Implementation Roadmap with outcome-based targets extending beyond chapter closure to 2031
Allocate a minimum of 5% of GDP to education as a pre-accession commitment, up from the current approximately 4%
Create a Teacher Retention and Development Fund using IPA III resources, targeting a 20% salary increase and mandatory continuous professional development
Establish dual-track VET programs with mandatory employer co-financing, modeled on the Austrian/German apprenticeship system adapted for small-state context
Launch a 'Stay and Research' scholarship program offering competitive domestic PhD and postdoc funding to counter brain drain
expected_benefits: Prevents hollow accession where formal compliance masks systemic education weaknesses
Creates measurable accountability framework that the EU Commission and European Parliament can monitor
Directly addresses brain drain by improving domestic education quality and employment prospects for graduates
Positions Montenegro as a model for substantive (not just formal) Western Balkans accession in education
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: Moderately feasible. The formal chapter closure component aligns with the PM's timeline. The binding roadmap would require negotiation with the European Commission but has precedent in post-accession Cooperation and Verification Mechanisms (CVM) used for Romania and Bulgaria. The 5% GDP target is ambitious given fiscal constraints but could be partially offset by increased IPA III absorption. Political will is the main variable.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Strategija pristupanja u oblasti obrazovanja sa naglaskom na suštinu
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Umjesto da se poglavlja o obrazovanju tretiraju kao stavke koje treba formalno zatvoriti do decembra 2026. godine, Ministarstvo bi predložilo paralelni pristup: formalno zatvaranje poglavlja praćeno obavezujućim Planom implementacije pristupanja u oblasti obrazovanja za period od 5 godina (2026–2031) s mjerljivim ciljevima ishoda (npr. poboljšanje PISA rezultata, stope završetka strukovnog obrazovanja i osposobljavanja, metrike naučnih rezultata, ciljevi smanjenja odliva mozgova). To bi omogućilo Crnoj Gori da održi zamah u procesu pristupanja, uz istovremeno osiguravanje da članstvo u EU bude potkrijepljeno stvarnim kapacitetom obrazovnog sistema.
key_changes_mne: Usvajanje obavezujućeg Plana implementacije pristupanja u oblasti obrazovanja s ciljevima zasnovanim na ishodima koji se protežu nakon zatvaranja poglavlja, do 2031. godine
Opredjeljenje za minimum od 5% BDP-a za obrazovanje kao predpristupna obaveza, u poređenju s trenutnih oko 4%
Osnivanje Fonda za zadržavanje i razvoj nastavnog kadra korišćenjem sredstava IPA III, s ciljem povećanja plata za 20% i obaveznog kontinuiranog stručnog usavršavanja

Uspostavljanje programa strukovnog obrazovanja i osposobljavanja s dvostrukom putanjom uz obavezno sufinansiranje od strane poslodavaca, prema uzoru na austrijski/njemački sistem šegrtovanja prilagođen kontekstu malih država
Pokretanje stipendijskog programa 'Ostani i istražuj' koji nudi konkurentno domaće finansiranje doktorskih studija i postdoktorskih istraživanja radi suzbijanja odliva mozgova
expected_benefits_mne: Sprječava formalno pristupanje bez suštine, u kojemu prividna usklađenost prikriva sistemske slabosti obrazovanja
Stvara mjerljiv okvir odgovornosti koji mogu pratiti Evropska komisija i Evropski parlament
Direktno se bavi problemom odliva mozgova poboljšanjem kvaliteta domaćeg obrazovanja i izgledima za zapošljavanje diplomiranih studenata
Pozicionira Crnu Goru kao model suštinskog (a ne samo formalnog) pristupanja zapadnog Balkana u oblasti obrazovanja
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Umjereno ostvarivo. Komponenta formalnog zatvaranja poglavlja usklađena je s vremenskim okvirom predsjednika Vlade. Obavezujući plan zahtijevao bi pregovaranje s Evropskom komisijom, ali postoji presedan u mehanizmima saradnje i verifikacije (CVM) koji su korišćeni u periodu nakon pristupanja za Rumuniju i Bugarsku. Cilj od 5% BDP-a je ambiciozan s obzirom na fiskalna ograničenja, ali bi ga djelimično mogla kompenzovati povećana apsorpcija sredstava IPA III. Politička volja je ključna promjenljiva.

assessments.summary_mne: Opredijeljenost premijera da do decembra 2026. zatvori sva pregovaračka poglavlja sa EU generalno je pozitivna za obrazovni sektor, jer stvara snažan politički zamah za usklađivanje crnogorskog obrazovnog sistema sa standardima EU. Međutim, 'ambicioznost bez presedana' ovog vremenskog okvira izaziva ozbiljne zabrinutosti u pogledu toga da li se mjerila vezana za obrazovanje – posebno u Poglavlju 26 (Obrazovanje i kultura) i Poglavlju 25 (Nauka i istraživanje) – mogu suštinski ispuniti, umjesto da se samo formalno zatvore, čime se riskirа površinska usklađenost nauštrb istinske reforme.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ovaj ambiciozni pristupni kurs ka EU pozitivan je za obrazovanje jer ubrzava usklađivanje s evropskim standardima, ali stisnuti rok – decembar 2026. – prijeti tome da se postigne papirna usklađenost umjesto stvarnog napretka u kvalitetu nastave, reformi strukovnog obrazovanja i istraživačkim kapacitetima. Ključna zabrinutost Ministarstva jeste da obrazovna poglavlja mogu biti na brzinu zatvorena bez rješavanja strukturnih slabosti kao što su odliv mozgova, nedovoljno finansirani univerziteti i loši rezultati na PISA testiranjima.
key_concerns_mne: Stisnuti vremenski okvir prijeti formalnoj/papirnoj usklađenosti u Poglavlju 26 (Obrazovanje i kultura) bez suštinskog napretka u kvalitetu nastave ili ishodima učenika
Odliv mozgova može se ubrzati kako pristupanje EU postaje opipljivije, bez paralelnih ulaganja u kvalitet domaćeg obrazovanja i zapošljavanje diplomaca
Jaz u rezultatima PISA testiranja ostaje nerješen i ne može se prevazići samim zatvaranjem poglavlja – crnogorski rezultati znatno zaostaju za prosjekom EU

Reforma strukovnog obrazovanja i obuke (VET) – uključujući učenje zasnovano na radu, partnerstva s poslodavcima i osiguranje kvaliteta – zahtijeva višegodišnji institucionalni razvoj koji se ne može ubrzati radi ispunjenja roka u decembru 2026.
Univerzitet Crne Gore i istraživačke institucije nemaju dovoljna sredstva ni kapacitete da na smislen način ispune mjerila Poglavlja 25 (Nauka i istraživanje)
Izazovi vezani za nastavnički kadar (niske plate, nedovoljan stručni razvoj, starenje radne snage) strukturne su prirode i postoji rizik da budu marginalizovani u korist zakonodavno lakših mjerila
recommendations_mne: Osigurati da obrazovni sektor dobije poseban akcioni plan u okviru ubrzanog pristupnog procesa, s konkretnim prekretnicama za Poglavlje 26 i Poglavlje 25 koje prevazilaze puko zakonodavno usklađivanje
Pregovarati s Evropskom komisijom o prelaznim periodima implementacije za obrazovna mjerila koja zahtijevaju višegodišnju izgradnju kapaciteta, čak i ako poglavlja budu formalno zatvorena
Maksimalno iskoristiti apsorpciju sredstava iz IPA III i programa Erasmus+ specifično za obuku nastavnika, modernizaciju strukovnog obrazovanja i istraživačke kapacitete univerziteta

Uspostaviti jedinicu za praćenje i ublažavanje odliva mozgova vezanu za pristupni proces, koja prati podatke o emigraciji mladih i povezuje podsticaje za zadržavanje s programima stipendija koje finansira EU
Ubrzati usklađivanje Crnogorskog okvira kvalifikacija (COK) sa standardima EQF nivoa 5–8, posebno za mikrokredencijale u strukovnom i visokom obrazovanju

Koristiti angažman u AFET-u za zalaganje za uključivanje Crne Gore u istraživačke okvirne programe EU (status pridružene zemlje u programu Horizont Evropa) kao konkretnu korist od pristupanja za obrazovni i istraživački sektor

assessments.summary: The Prime Minister's meeting with the AFET delegation and the stated ambition to close all EU negotiating chapters by December 2026 is a politically significant signal, but from an environmental perspective it raises serious concerns about whether Chapter 27 — historically the most complex and resource-intensive chapter in any EU accession process — can be credibly closed within approximately ten months. While the political commitment to EU integration is welcome, the gap between rhetorical ambition and the actual state of environmental transposition, implementation, and enforcement in Montenegro remains vast.
assessments.executive_summary: The PM's goal of closing all chapters by December 2026 is politically bold but environmentally unrealistic without transformative acceleration on Chapter 27. Montenegro still faces critical deficits in waste management infrastructure, air quality compliance, wastewater treatment, EIA enforcement, and Natura 2000 preparation. The Ministry of Environment urges that the timeline not be used to justify superficial legislative alignment without genuine implementation capacity.
assessments.reasoning:
Chapter 27 (Environment and Climate Change) is universally acknowledged as the most demanding chapter in EU accession negotiations, covering over 200 pieces of EU legislation across air quality, water management, waste, nature protection, industrial pollution, chemicals, noise, climate change, and civil protection. Croatia, the most recent Western Balkan accession, needed years of intensive work on this chapter alone, and even upon accession had extensive transitional periods.

Montenegro's current situation presents multiple structural challenges. On waste management, the country still lacks a functioning regional sanitary landfill system; illegal dumping remains widespread; recycling rates are far below EU averages; and the circular economy legislative framework is incomplete. The waste crisis, particularly in municipalities like Podgorica, Nikšić, and along the coast, is a daily reality that cannot be resolved by legislative transposition alone — it requires physical infrastructure that takes years to build.

On air quality, TPP Pljevlja continues to operate well above EU emission limits for SO2, NOx, and particulate matter. The Large Combustion Plant Directive and Industrial Emissions Directive require either massive retrofitting or a clear phase-out timeline, neither of which is firmly in place. Pljevlja's citizens suffer direct health consequences, and the European Commission has repeatedly flagged this issue.

Water and wastewater management infrastructure remains critically underdeveloped. Most Montenegrin municipalities lack secondary or tertiary wastewater treatment. The Urban Wastewater Treatment Directive alone would require investments of hundreds of millions of euros and construction timelines extending well beyond 2026.

Nature protection and biodiversity present another gap. Montenegro has not yet formally designated Natura 2000 sites, a prerequisite for Chapter 27 closure. The biogeographical assessment, habitat mapping, and species inventories are still incomplete. National parks — Durmitor, Biogradska Gora, Prokletije, Lake Skadar, and Lovćen — face ongoing pressures from illegal construction, unregulated tourism, and insufficient management capacity. Lake Skadar's transboundary management with Albania under the Ramsar Convention remains a diplomatic and ecological challenge.

Coastal zone management along the Adriatic is under severe pressure from uncontrolled construction, inadequate spatial planning, and tourism overdevelopment. The alignment with the Barcelona Convention Protocol on ICZM and EU marine strategy frameworks is still nascent.

The Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) and Strategic Environmental Assessment (SEA) systems, while formally in place, suffer from weak enforcement, political interference, and insufficient public participation — issues the European Commission has repeatedly documented in its annual progress reports.

The PM's statement is diplomatically appropriate and the political commitment to EU integration is genuinely positive. However, the Ministry of Environment is concerned that framing an 'unprecedented' timeline creates pressure to prioritize legislative box-ticking over genuine implementation. The EU accession process for Chapter 27 is not merely about transposing directives into national law — it is about building institutional capacity, enforcement mechanisms, monitoring systems, and physical infrastructure. Rushing this process risks producing a hollow alignment that will be exposed during post-accession monitoring or, worse, during interim benchmarks that could stall the process entirely.

Wastewater treatment infrastructure deficit requires hundreds of millions of euros in investment and years of construction

Coastal zone illegal construction and spatial planning failures remain unresolved and directly conflict with EU ICZM and marine directives
EIA/SEA enforcement weaknesses and political interference in environmental permitting undermine the credibility of the regulatory framework
recommendations: Develop a realistic Chapter 27 implementation roadmap with clearly sequenced milestones, identifying which benchmarks can be met by December 2026 and which will require transitional periods post-accession
Immediately accelerate Natura 2000 site designation by allocating additional resources to the Environmental Protection Agency for habitat mapping and species inventories
Establish a firm and publicly communicated phase-out timeline for TPP Pljevlja, with interim emission reduction measures to demonstrate good faith to the European Commission
Prioritize procurement and construction of regional waste management infrastructure, engaging EU IPA III funds and EIB/EBRD financing to the maximum extent possible

counter_proposal.title: Credible Chapter 27 Roadmap with Transitional Period Strategy
counter_proposal.summary: Rather than framing Chapter 27 closure as achievable by December 2026 in full implementation terms, the Ministry of Environment would propose an honest, technically grounded approach: present the European Commission with a comprehensive National Plan for Environmental Acquis Implementation that demonstrates full legislative transposition, a credible investment pipeline for infrastructure gaps, strengthened institutional capacity, and negotiated transitional periods for the most capital-intensive directives (waste, wastewater, industrial emissions). This approach mirrors the successful Croatian model and would actually accelerate chapter closure by building Commission confidence rather than overpromising.
key_changes: Adopt a phased compliance strategy distinguishing between legislative transposition (achievable by end-2026) and full operational compliance (requiring transitional periods of 3-7 years post-accession for waste, wastewater, and industrial emissions)
Create a dedicated Chapter 27 Implementation Task Force with ring-fenced budget, staffed with EU-seconded experts, and direct reporting to the Deputy PM for EU Integration
Launch an emergency Natura 2000 designation programme with a target of completing the proposed site list by Q3 2026
Negotiate a binding Energy Community Treaty roadmap for TPP Pljevlja phase-out as part of the National Energy and Climate Plan
Publish a transparent Chapter 27 progress dashboard accessible to the public, civil society, and the European Commission
expected_benefits: Greater credibility with the European Commission, which values realistic planning over unrealistic promises
Avoidance of a credibility crisis if December 2026 full closure proves impossible for Chapter 27
Structured access to EU pre-accession and post-accession environmental funds through a well-documented investment pipeline
Genuine environmental improvement for Montenegrin citizens rather than paper compliance
Stronger negotiating position for transitional periods based on demonstrated good faith and concrete progress
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High. This approach is modeled on Croatia's successful Chapter 27 negotiation strategy, which involved negotiated transitional periods for the most investment-heavy directives while demonstrating full legislative alignment and institutional readiness. Montenegro can realistically achieve legislative transposition and present a credible implementation plan by December 2026, even if full operational compliance for infrastructure-dependent directives will require additional years.

assessments.summary: The Prime Minister's engagement with the AFET delegation and reaffirmation of the goal to close all EU negotiating chapters by December 2026 is a welcome signal of political commitment to European integration. However, from a justice perspective, the ambition must be matched by substantive reforms in the rule of law cluster—particularly Chapters 23 and 24—which have historically been the most difficult benchmarks for Montenegro. The rhetoric of 'unprecedented' speed risks prioritizing form over substance if judicial independence, anti-corruption enforcement, and human rights protections are not genuinely embedded rather than legislated on paper alone.
assessments.executive_summary: The Ministry of Justice views this engagement positively as a reaffirmation of EU accession commitment, but warns that closing Chapter 23 by December 2026 requires demonstrable track records in judicial independence, anti-corruption prosecutions, and human rights enforcement—not merely legislative alignment. The top concern is that political urgency may incentivize cosmetic compliance over genuine rule-of-law reform.
assessments.reasoning:
Montenegro opened Chapter 23 (Judiciary and Fundamental Rights) in December 2013, making it one of the longest-running negotiation chapters. The European Commission's annual reports have consistently identified interim benchmarks that remain only partially fulfilled, particularly regarding: (1) the track record of final convictions in high-level corruption and organized crime cases; (2) genuine independence of the prosecutorial and judicial councils from political influence; (3) implementation of the revised Law on the Judicial Council and the Law on the State Prosecution, which must demonstrate functional independence, not merely statutory provisions; and (4) freedom of expression and media freedom, where threats and attacks against journalists remain inadequately prosecuted.

The Prime Minister's characterization of the timeline as 'unprecedented' is accurate and, to his credit, honest. However, this honesty must translate into an equally honest assessment of what remains unfinished. The Special State Prosecutor's Office (SDT) has struggled with capacity, independence perceptions, and the slow processing of complex financial crime cases. The Agency for Prevention of Corruption (ASK) has improved its institutional framework but still faces questions about enforcement consistency, particularly regarding asset declarations and conflict-of-interest proceedings involving senior officials.

From a constitutional compliance standpoint, the meeting itself raises no concerns—it falls squarely within the executive's foreign affairs competence under Articles 14 and 95 of the Montenegrin Constitution. The political call for support from all 27 EU member states is diplomatically sound but sidesteps the domestic dimension: Montenegro's progress depends primarily on its own institutional performance, not on external political goodwill.

The Venice Commission has issued multiple opinions on Montenegro's judicial reform legislation, most recently emphasizing that the composition and selection procedures of the Judicial Council must be insulated from parliamentary political dynamics. The 2023 constitutional amendments to the judicial appointment process were a step forward, but their implementation track record is still being evaluated by the Commission and the European Commission alike.

Regarding human rights, closing Chapter 23 requires demonstrated progress on Roma inclusion, LGBTQ+ rights enforcement, disability rights, and access to justice for vulnerable populations. Legislative frameworks exist, but implementation gaps remain significant, particularly outside Podgorica.

The risk of this ambitious timeline is not the ambition itself but the potential for 'checkbox diplomacy'—rushing legislation through parliament without adequate public consultation, independent scrutiny, or implementation capacity. This was seen in earlier phases of Montenegro's accession process and was specifically criticized by the European Commission in its 2024 enlargement report.

McAllister's confirmation that Montenegro is among the most advanced candidates is encouraging but should not breed complacency. Being 'most advanced' in the Western Balkans context still means significant gaps relative to EU member state standards, particularly in judicial efficiency, anti-corruption enforcement, and media freedom.

The Special State Prosecutor's Office (SDT) still lacks a robust track record of final convictions in high-level corruption cases, a core interim benchmark for Chapter 23 closure
Judicial Council and Prosecutorial Council independence remains under scrutiny; rushed reforms could entrench rather than resolve political influence concerns
Human rights implementation gaps—particularly for Roma, LGBTQ+ communities, and persons with disabilities—risk being deprioritized in favor of 'easier' benchmarks
Media freedom and journalist safety prosecutions remain inadequate, which the European Commission tracks as a Chapter 23 benchmark
Public consultation and parliamentary scrutiny may be curtailed under time pressure, undermining democratic legitimacy of reform legislation
The framing of accession as dependent on '27 member states' political backing' risks deflecting attention from domestic reform obligations
recommendations: Publish a detailed, time-bound action plan for remaining Chapter 23 interim benchmarks with quarterly milestones, subject to independent monitoring by civil society and the EU Delegation
Strengthen SDT capacity through targeted recruitment of financial crime specialists and ensure operational independence from political interference, including secure multi-year budgeting
Accelerate processing of pending high-level corruption cases to build the track record of final convictions demanded by the European Commission
Ensure all reform legislation undergoes meaningful public consultation (minimum 30 days) and Venice Commission review where applicable, even under accelerated timelines

Maintain transparency on the gap between legislative adoption and actual enforcement, reporting honestly to the European Commission rather than presenting aspirational compliance

counter_proposal.title: Substance-First Accession Roadmap for Chapter 23
counter_proposal.summary: Rather than framing accession progress around a politically driven December 2026 deadline, the Ministry of Justice would anchor the Chapter 23 closure strategy in measurable enforcement outcomes—final convictions, judicial efficiency metrics, and human rights implementation indicators—with the timeline following substance rather than substance following the timeline. This means accepting that some benchmarks may require early 2027 completion if genuine reform quality demands it, while demonstrating to the EU that Montenegro prioritizes durable rule-of-law standards over symbolic deadlines.
key_changes: Replace the single December 2026 political deadline with a phased benchmark-by-benchmark closure schedule, publicly tracked and independently verified
Prioritize a minimum of five final convictions in high-level corruption cases before requesting provisional closure of Chapter 23, rather than relying on legislative metrics alone
Mandate Venice Commission review for any constitutional or organic law amendments related to judicial governance adopted under the accelerated timeline

Create a Justice Reform Dashboard—a publicly accessible, real-time tracker of key Chapter 23 indicators including case processing times, conviction rates, ASK enforcement actions, and human rights complaint resolution
Ring-fence SDT and judicial reform budgets from mid-year rebalancing to prevent political leverage over reform institutions
expected_benefits: Greater credibility with the European Commission and member states, potentially accelerating rather than delaying actual chapter closure
Reduced risk of post-accession rule-of-law backsliding, as seen in some Central European member states that prioritized speed over substance
Stronger public trust in the accession process through transparency and measurable accountability
Insulation of judicial and prosecutorial independence from the political pressures inherent in deadline-driven reform
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High. This approach requires political will to accept flexible timelines but imposes no additional financial burden and aligns with the European Commission's own methodology, which has consistently emphasized track records over legislative output. The main obstacle is political—it requires the government to temper its messaging from 'December 2026 at all costs' to 'as soon as genuine readiness permits, targeting December 2026.'

Smanjen rizik od nazadovanja u oblasti vladavine prava nakon pristupanja, kakvo je zabilježeno u nekim državama članicama srednje Evrope koje su brzini dale prednost nad suštinom

assessments.summary: The Prime Minister's meeting with the AFET delegation and the stated ambition to close all EU negotiating chapters by December 2026 sends a strong political signal that, if credible, can positively influence investor confidence, sovereign risk perception, and access to EU pre-accession funds. However, the fiscal implications of accelerated alignment — particularly in chapters such as Chapter 16 (Taxation), Chapter 17 (Economic and Monetary Policy), Chapter 22 (Regional Policy), and Chapter 32 (Financial Control) — are substantial and require significant budgetary commitment that has not been publicly detailed alongside this political declaration.
assessments.executive_summary: The EU accession ambition is fiscally positive in the medium term — improving credit ratings, attracting FDI, and unlocking IPA III funds — but the Ministry of Finance notes the absence of a concrete fiscal roadmap to support the political timeline. Montenegro opened accession negotiations in June 2012 and has opened all 33 chapters, with three provisionally closed (25 — Science and Research, 26 — Education and Culture, and 30 — External Relations). Closing the remaining 30 chapters by December 2026 — roughly 10 months from this meeting — would indeed be without precedent. For context, Croatia took over eight years from opening to closing negotiations.

The political value of this meeting is clear. AFET is the key European Parliament committee shaping the political narrative around enlargement, and David McAllister, as its long-standing chair and rapporteur on the Western Balkans, is among the most influential voices on EU enlargement policy. Securing his public confirmation that Montenegro and Albania are the most advanced candidates is diplomatically significant, particularly as the EU's revised enlargement methodology and the Growth Plan for the Western Balkans have injected new momentum into the process.

However, the Ministry of EU Integration must assess credibility, not just ambition. The European Commission's annual progress reports have consistently identified the same structural deficiencies: insufficient independence and capacity of the judiciary (Chapter 23), weak track records on corruption convictions — particularly high-level corruption — and organized crime prosecutions (Chapter 24), limited media freedom, and politicization of public administration. The interim benchmarks for Chapters 23 and 24 have not yet been fully met, and these chapters operate under the 'new approach' whereby they are opened first and closed last, serving as the overall barometer of reform credibility.

Closing all chapters requires not only legislative alignment with the acquis but demonstrated track records of implementation. The EU's requirement is not paper compliance but systemic change — functioning courts, independent prosecutors, measurable anti-corruption outcomes, and sustainable institutional capacity. The December 2026 timeline implies that Montenegro would need to satisfy closing benchmarks across all remaining chapters within months, which would require an extraordinary acceleration in both legislative output and institutional performance.

The call for political backing from all 27 member states is strategically important but also highlights a vulnerability: even if Montenegro meets all technical requirements, any single member state can block chapter closure for political reasons. Recent enlargement dynamics — including the French-led push for methodology reform and various bilateral disputes in the region — underscore that political consensus is not automatic.

The positive elements include: (1) sustained high-level engagement with EU institutions, (2) alignment with the current pro-enlargement window in Brussels driven by geopolitical considerations (Russia-Ukraine context), (3) McAllister's endorsement reinforcing Montenegro's frontrunner narrative, and (4) implicit pressure on domestic institutions to deliver. The risks include: (1) credibility erosion if the December 2026 target is missed without demonstrable progress, (2) the 'unprecedented' framing pre-emptively normalizing failure, (3) insufficient attention to the substance behind the timeline, and (4) potential fatigue among EU interlocutors if ambitious targets are repeatedly set and missed.
